title: Paraview Problems
body:
I've been using the issues here to solve some of my own problems with applications not installing, so I'm just going to document some issues I had with installing Paraview that I solved, but haven't decided on the best way to put back into Spack.

When installing Paraview I found that it downloads a tar file like normal which has a `version.txt` file in it which contains `5.4.1` for example. The cmake configure then does a `find_package(git)` and if the Git executable exists, it runs `git describe` and uses whatever this output may be, which in my case was `0.8.17-6535-g5ccc9c1` for whatever reason:

```
-- Found Git: /usr/bin/git (found version "1.7.1") 
-- Determined Source Version : 0.8.17-6535-g5ccc9c1
```

Then Paraview is happy to consider itself version 0.8 and when trying to connect with a 5.4.1 client, it fails. The solution for me was to stop Paraview from running `git describe` by commenting it out in the CMakeLists.txt and then it defaults to using `version.txt`:

```
-- Could not use git to determine source version, using version 5.4.1
```

Which then worked fine.

Next the Paraview library files are then installed into `lib/paraview-5.4` rather than the normal `lib` directory itself, so I had to modify the module file that was generated.

I would like to put this back into Spack, but I'm not sure of the best way to deal with the `git describe` issue, by either a patch, or whatever since I'm not sure if my patch will only work for 5.4.x. I feel like it might almost be best to hide `git` from Paraview before configure somehow to solve the problem for all Paraview versions. I will submit this issue to Paraview.

The module file should be easy to generate the correct library path, but I haven't looked into how to customize module file generation yet.

Anyway just documenting my experience in case anyone else deals with Paraview. I will try to get my modifications put back into Spack in the right manner if I find the time.
